benchmark_details.name: MARPLE (Multimodal Agent Reasoning for Long-Horizon Evaluation)
benchmark_details.overview: MARPLE is a benchmark for evaluating long-horizon inference capabilities using multi-modal evidence. It features agents interacting with simulated households, supporting visual, language, and auditory stimuli to infer causal relationships in household scenarios, primarily focused on 'whodunit' style questions.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To assess models' abilities to perform long-horizon multimodal inference in complex household scenarios.

data.source: Procedurally generated multimodal data from the MARPLE Household Simulator.
data.size: 5000 trajectories for training datasets, 500 trajectories for test datasets.
data.annotation: Automatically generated through the MARPLE Household Simulator.

metrics: Inference accuracy at various time steps
methodology.calculation: Inference accuracy is calculated based on the probability of correctly identifying the agent responsible for a query state.
methodology.interpretation: Higher inference accuracy indicates a better understanding and prediction of agent behaviors and state changes.
methodology.baseline_results: Human participants achieved an average accuracy of 0.8 with 48% of evidence.
methodology.validation: Benchmarks were validated through comparisons with human performance and established baselines.
